How I Compressed a Week of Agency R&D into a Single Day with Gemini Gems

üè∑Ô∏è Case Study ‚ö° AI Workflow
Published: 14 January 2026

The new agency workflow: AI as the first line of defense.

In the professional services world‚Äîwhether you run an agency, a consultancy, or a freelance practice‚Äîthere is a hidden killer of profitability: The Fact-Find.

We usually call it "onboarding" or "discovery," but let‚Äôs call it what it really is: a 2-hour interrogation where you ask the same 20 questions to figure out if a client is even worth working with.

  • "What‚Äôs your budget?"
  • "Who are your competitors?"
  • "What are your unit economics?"

If you do this manually, it burns hours of senior partner time. If you delegate it to a junior, they miss the nuance.

Yesterday, I decided to automate myself out of this loop. I built an AI Agent (specifically, a Google Gemini Gem) to handle the entire "Service-Led Diagnostic" process‚Äîfrom initial intake to generating a confidential analyst brief.

üìã The Result

  • Input: Manual conversation with prospect
  • Process: "Integrity Gate" logic to filter bad fits
  • Output: Structured Confidential Analyst Brief
  • Time to Build: 24 Hours (vs ~5 Days traditionally)

Try the Gem (Demo) ‚Üí

The Illusion of "One-Shot" Prompting

When I started, I fell into the classic trap: I thought it would be easy.

I assumed I could just paste my SOPs into Gemini and say, "You are now an analyst. Go."

I was wrong.

The first version was a disaster. It was sycophantic ("Great answer!"), it hallucinated pricing, and it asked 15 questions in a single wall of text that would make any prospect close the tab immediately.

What followed wasn‚Äôt "coding" in the traditional sense, but it was just as rigorous. I went through 10 full iterations of the system prompt to get the behavior right.

Why 10? Because halfway through, I realized I was approaching it completely wrong. I had to revert to a structured product development process:

  1. Technical Spec: Defining the exact logic gates.
  2. Sectional Build: Prompting one module at a time.
  3. Cross-Model Validation: Checking logic validity across models.
  4. Real-Life Stress Test: I tested it against a live case study (Davin Choo).

It was only when I fed it Davin's real-world constraints (limited hours, manual tracking) that I witnessed the breakdown. The Agent initially suggested generic "Facebook Ads," ignoring that Davin had absolutely no time to service more leads. I had to hard-code an "Integrity Gate" to force the Agent to suggest operational leverage (hiring/systems) instead of marketing when the client is at capacity.

The breakthrough wasn't the AI's intelligence; it was that contextual awareness.

The Integrity Gate: Hard-coding ethics into the logic flow.

The Solution: Hard-coding Ethics

I had to teach it:

  1. To be Sequential: "Stop asking for everything at once. Ask one thing, wait for the answer."
  2. To be Skeptical: "If the user says 'I don't know my revenue', don't just say 'Okay.' Provide a base rate and force an estimate."
  3. To have 'Bedside Manner': Contextualising scary terms like 'COGS' so a creative freelancer doesn't feel alienated.

The Velocity of AI (vs. The Old Way)

The biggest takeaway for me wasn't that the AI is "smart"‚Äîit‚Äôs that it compresses complex reasoning development.

To build this level of reasoning traditionally (React App + Logic Tree), I would need:

Monday - Tuesday

Map the decision tree (Concept).

Wednesday

Brief a developer to build a custom React app (Execution).

Thursday

Realize the "bedside manner" is robotic and rewrite all the copy.

Friday

Fix bugs.

Total time: 5 Days.

With Gemini, the schedule was compressed into 24 Hours.

Morning

Draft the "System Identity" prompt.

Afternoon

Realize prompt is broken -> Pivot to structured specs.

Evening

Run case study tests.

Night

Final polish and write-up.

The massive unlock here is compounding speed. This first agent took me 24 hours to plan and ship because I had to relearn the process. The next agent I build will likely take half a day.

The Final Output

The final result is a publicly available Gem that acts as a Senior Intake Analyst. It doesn‚Äôt just collect data; it continuously builds a mental model of the business and outputs a structured Confidential Analyst Brief at the end.

The Output: A structured Analyst Brief generated in real-time.
